title: 78s and the "Golden Age of Thai Song": Content and Analysis of the Thai 78 rpm Discographical Framework
summary: The Thai 78 rpm Discographical Framework is a complete listing of all known 78 rpm recordings of Thai music, the first of its kind for any Southeast Asian nation. Initial analysis of the Framework and its content suggests that a significant but as yet unacknowledged factor in the "golden age of Thai song" in the 1960s was the overlap between 78 rpm technology and 45 and 33 rpm technology. When major companies abandoned the 78 rpm format, singer-songwriters and small publishing companies gained a foothold in the Thai recording industry. The result was the industry's fragmentation and increased creativity.

ordered_authors.display_name: JAMES L E O N A R D MITCHELL

title: “SHOW-TIME” FOR THE SINDHEN, OR THE TIME OF LIMBUKAN: NEW PERFORMING PRACTICES AND MUSICAL REPERTOIRES IN THE COMIC INTERLUDE OF YOGYANESE WAYANG KULIT
summary: Wayang kulit (shadow puppet theatre) has an ancient and glorious tradition in Java (Indonesia), especially in the Courtly Centers of Surakarta and Yogyakarta. This performing art has been continuously developing across the centuries, since the Majapahit Empire (ca. 9th century) until nowadays. During the Dutch Rule (ca. 17th-20th century) the performance practice of wayang kulit had undergone a standardization, thus crystallizing into the “classical” form. However, wayang kulit has continued to evolve, and still now external influences determines interesting changes in its performance practice. The two comic interludes (Limbukan and Gara-Gara) offer the greatest possibility to insert innovations in the “classical” format. In particular the Limbukan, the most recently added, constitutes the highest breaking point of the “classical” structure: it represents an open sequence, not linked with the mythological narration of the wayang. Here, new humorous spectacular practices and musical repertoires lead by female protagonists (sindhen) take place. This paper investigates the most relevant changes happening in this comic interlude: on one hand the interaction between the sindhen and the dhalang (puppeteer), on the other hand the mix of traditional and contemporary genres in musical repertoires. In order to show these innovations, I will take as an example the Limbukan performed by the famous dalang Ki Nugroho Suseno on March, 2015 in Yogyakarta.

research_interests.name: Innovations and Changes in the field of Music
Music and music education within the context of socio-cultural changes

title: Music and the cline of Malayness: sounds of egalitarianism and ranking
summary: The cline of Malayness as exhibited in Sumatra and the Malay Peninsula extends through tribal-Malay, rakyat-Malay, aristocrat-Malay and modern urban-Malay. As a consequence of the manner in which Malay states came into being, this cline exhibits an increasing elaboration of the cultural expression of transition and transitivity. This is manifested in the different manners of musical performance favoured in the various Malay populations. In turn, these differences are paralleled closely in such other areas of Malay cultural expression as: social personality, cooking & eating, dance, religion, grammar & lexicon. Fifteen illustrative audio examples are available on the Soundcloud.com website through links given in the footnotes, where links to other cited online audio examples are also provided.

title: “音乐特境”之形塑： 以印度尼西亚穆罕默德诞辰庆祝活动为例
summary:
在印度尼西亚的穆斯林三大庆祝活动中，以“印度尼西亚穆罕默德诞辰庆祝活动”（garebeg mulud）最为丰富。为期八天穆罕的默德诞辰庆祝活动，除了一些庆祝方式(穆罕默德的生平事迹讲述仪式、念诵古兰经、宗教诗歌唱诵)与其他穆斯林国家相同之外，印度尼西亚不同于其他穆斯林国家的特殊性在于，在音乐的使用上，选择了印度尼西亚传统音乐 —— 甘美朗西卡蒂（gamelan sekati）作为连贯整个庆祝活动的进行。

于印度尼西亚八天的庆祝活动中，由各种不同的声音景观所组成，包含甘美朗西卡蒂表演 、苏丹王掷钱祈福的 Udik-udik 仪式、米山奉献仪式等。本文将运用“音乐特境”（musikscape）的概念，来讨论印度尼西亚穆罕默德诞辰庆祝是如何透过人、时、地来形塑活动中各种展演的声音景观。而在诞辰庆典里的声音景观，又是如何在八天内不同的时间与空间中，构筑出独特的音乐特境，并反映出最初穆斯林圣人试图透过此活动来宣扬的伊斯兰宗教理念。

关键词：印度尼西亚穆罕默德诞辰庆祝活动；音乐特境；甘美朗西卡蒂；
Udik-udik 仪式；米山奉献仪式

title: Music Lessons: Piano Lessons as Life Lessons
The first Western music score of Nhạc Tài tử: historical contexts and musical analysis
summary:
Nhạc Tài tử is a genre of traditional music that emerged in Southern Vietnam during the nineteenth century. The first Tài tử performance in the West was part of the theatrical production "La Bague Enchantée" (The Magic Ring) at the 1900 Paris World Exposition, where Vietnamese musicians accompanied European dancers who were led by the famous French ballerina Cléo de Mérode. The musicologist Julien Tiersot attended this performance and met the leader of the Vietnamese musicians who helped Tiersot notate “the fundamental repertoire of (Tài tử) music performed at the Exposition” which was later published as "Danse de l’Indo-chine" (Dance of Indochina).  To date, this 110 years old notation is the first published Western music score of Nhạc Tài tử.
This paper will discuss the historical contexts which led to the collaboration between European dancers and Vietnamese musicians.  Analysis of the score will reveal traces of Tài tử music that are still currently performed in Vietnam.  A discussion, accompanied by live demonstrations on traditional Vietnamese music instruments, will illustrate theoretical principles of the Tài tử modes, ornamentations and expressive techniques which were not included in the score.  A comparative study will highlight similarities between the musical materials found in Tiersot’s notation and the Tài tử classic Ancient Repertoire. Based on new findings, this paper will also explore the hypothesis that "Danse de l’Indo-chine" reflects the performance order of Tài tử musical items in the theatrical production "La Bague Enchantée".  This ordering of musical materials may well have been chosen to support the dramatic storyline of the production.

Presenters: Le-Tuyen Nguyen (Australian National University) and 
Huynh Khai (Ho Chi Minh City Conservatory of Music)

research_interests.name: Vietnam, Vietnamese literature, Vietnamese language and culture

title: ￼Recording review: "LAOS. Musique des Khmou". Archives ￼Internationales de Musique Populaire et Musée d’Ethnographie de ￼Genève, 2017.
summary: Avec ce second CD consacré à la musique du Laos, les Archives internationales de musique populaire plongent les auditeurs dans la vie musicale des populations khmou du nord du pays. Les différentes plages offrent une exceptionnelle diversité de styles, d’ambiances et de timbres, pourtant tous issus de la tradition musicale d’un même groupe ethnique. Véronique de Lavenère, spécialiste des orgues à bouche du Laos et de la musique des populations austroasiatiques, partage avec nous dix-sept ans d’enregistrements chez les Khmou, du chant "teum" au jeu d’une flûte solitaire, de la vibration des bambous frappés au son d’une pousse de riz fraîchement coupée.

title: Malay art music composers and performers of Tanjungpinang and Pulau Penyengat
summary: This chapter was stimulated by the new music (kreasi baru) that the author heard at the 2011 Gawai/Lomba Seni in Tanjungpinang and at later performances and rehearsals on Pulau Penyengat and in Batam Centre, all in Kepulauan Riau (Kepri) province, Indonesia. Through interviews with the composers, the author has sought to uncover their specifically musical background and artistic aims against the background of the more ‘traditional’ Malay music-making still widely followed in the Bentan area. The author’s ten associated video and audio examples are available through links given in the footnotes, where links to other cited online audio examples are also provided.

title: KARAWITAN SUNDA: TRADITION NEWLY WRIT A survey of Sundanese (West Java) music since Independence
summary: A survey of the music of Sunda (West Java) in the years between Independence and 1980, and first published in 1982. Sundanese music differs in many ways from that of the court culture of the rest of Java, is more 'popular' and is not so dominated by the refinements of gamelan, having a much stronger tradition of song accompanied by zithers. The author discusses personalities, trends and styles, and innovations in instruments. The article concludes with a listing of a collection of recordings deposited with the British Library's sound archive.

title: The first Western music score of Nhạc Tài tử: historical contexts and musical analysis

title: The Timbre of Thai Classical Singing
summary: This article explores the timbre of Thai classical singing with an emphasis on uan, a wordless vocalization based upon specific vowels and consonants, using spectrographic images. Spectrographs are computer images that visualize the fundamental, overtones, and noise-like sounds of a performance. Uan can be reduced to five basic sounds and are analyzed individually and then placed within a musical context. Performances from different generations and musical lineages are contrasted and compared in relation to timbre. I argue it is the relative timbral consistency of the five basic uan sounds, connecting musical generations and lineages, combined with the unique characteristics of each performance that defines the distinct sound of Thai classical singing.

title: Suraphon Sombatjaroen on 78 rpm:  The development of Thailand’s king of music business
summary: Suraphon Sombatjaroen (1930-1968), still known as 'the king of Thai country song', has become a legendary figure in Thailand, dominating all discussion of early lukthung. Thailand's popular media (television, film and newspapers) regularly present the romantic image of Suraphon as an individual artistic genius killed in his prime. However, his recording and business history has received little scholarly attention. This article describes Suraphon's use of the 78 rpm record format and his exploitation of the emerging lukthung audience in order to contribute to a fuller understanding of the Thai popular music industry during the 1950s and 1960s. Through the skilful manipulation and management of audience tastes, band personnel and content provision, Suraphon became the first Thai artist to bring song writing, performance, recording process, management and promotion completely under his own control. Suraphon Sombatjaroen on 78 rpm

title: Knowledge Transmission of Gamelan Music in Java: Change and Continuity (Paper presented at the BFE Annual Conference, Kent, April 2016)
summary:
During the twentieth century many changes occurred in Indonesia that affected knowledge transmission in Javanese gamelan music. Growing up during the early-to-mid twentieth century, children of performing arts families would spend their time at wayang and gamelan performances; they rarely attended formal education past primary school and were immersed in gamelan music nearly every night. Performing as part of a large extended family they were expected to quickly pick up the instruments of the gamelan from exposure and absorption alone.  
The advent of compulsory schooling, along with the high value placed on education by many Javanese, has fundamentally altered how children spend their time; they can no longer stay up all night at a wayang performance before school. State-sponsored specialist arts institutions have become the sole route to a successful career as a musician. All aspiring professional gamelan musicians attend these schools, which have been accused of promoting institutionalised musical styles rather than teaching material as it would be played in performance.
The smaller family size common nowadays, with a tendency to move out of the family home and live as a separate nuclear family, means that large family performances are less feasible. Such family changes have affected the performance culture. In a region where performances are usually funded by the host, a smaller family is less likely to sponsor a large-scale performance with a whole gamelan troupe. This means that performances are less frequent, and has made learning through performing more difficult.
Based on original fieldwork, this paper examines how changes in schooling, the family and the performance culture have affected knowledge transmission of gamelan music in Java, and shows that despite such drastic change, many children of performing arts families continue to become musicians, finding ways to combine knowledge gained from school with that from their own families.

title: Nicolas 2012 ฆ้อง กระดิ่ง-กระพรวน และฉาบ หลักฐานการค้าโลกข้ามสมุทรฉบับเอเชีย ในช่วงศตวรรษที่ 9-17 ศิริพจน์ เหล่ามานะเจริญ แปลเก็บความจาก Gongs, Bells and Cymbals: The Archaeological Record in Maritime Asia from the 9th to the 17th centuries

title: Kurosawa Takatomo’s 1939 Fieldwork in Southeast Asia and His Study of Taiwanese Indigenous Music
summary: Kurosawa Takatomo (1895-1987) was the first Japanese musicologist to conduct fieldwork in Southeast Asia in 1939. He was also a key member of the team that carried out the first comprehensive survey of Taiwanese music in 1943. In the past, his 1939 fieldwork in Southeast Asia has been long neglected except for the publication of his field diary compiled by Umeda in 1997. Although his work on Taiwanese indigenous music has been regarded as a canon on the subject, no study has examined how his fieldwork in Southeast Asia informed and influenced his study of Taiwanese indigenous music. After combing through Kurosawa’s canonic book on Taiwanese indigenous music published in 1973, I found that the book made many references to Southeast Asian music. Furthermore, I discovered that most of these references were based on the information and materials that Kurosawa collected in his 1939 fieldwork in Southeast Asia and afterwards. Most importantly I found that one of Kurosawa’s main points in his 1973 book is to suggest that Taiwanese indigenous music originated from the music of Southeast Asia but went through changes afterwards. Using Kurosawa’s 1973 book and his archival materials now preserved at the National Taiwan University Library as my primary data, I provide preliminary observations on how Kurosawa’s 1939 fieldwork in Southeast Asia informed and influenced his subsequent study of Taiwanese indigenous music. By doing so, I hope to fill the above-mentioned gaps by bringing attention to Kurosawa’s 1939 fieldwork in Southeast Asia and its importance to his life-long devotion to organology and to his study of Taiwanese indigenous music.

title: Beyond Rhythm: Exploring Infinite Possibilities in Music, Movement and Choreography–Hands Percussion Malaysia
The Demise of the Gurukula system in Asia and the Condition of Music Tradition in the Post-Industrial Era
summary: Rapid developments in media and communications technology have affected the manner in which we carry out our research. Techniques that were not long ago very challenging and expensive have now become in large measure very easy. Attitudes about what is possible and what is worthy of study have changed. To what degree have these changes affected the object of so much of what many of us study; the contemporary manifestation of the traditional arts of the world? Are these changes inevitable, universal? What does the future look like if we continue on this path?

title: “Home grown music is tasty”: liminality and locality in a musical community in the city of Solo, Central Java, Indonesia
summary: On the edge of Solo, a city famous for its rich cultural heritage, a graffiti-covered boarding house was home to a musical community making music including reggae, metal and traditionally-inspired percussion fusion. Drawing on ethnographic fieldwork and theoretical perspectives on musical communities (Finnegan 1989, Cohen 1991), this paper explores the distinctive ways in which these musicians negotiated their unique social and musical positions. Socially, I situate the community as at once liminal and unconventional yet firmly rooted in its place and local identity, drawing selectively on elements of the monolithic ‘Javanese culture’. Musically, I show how the community blurred boundaries between genres assumed to have distinct ‘scenes’, and between popular and traditional musics, forming a point of connection between state-endorsed versions of Indonesian culture and global youth subcultures. Together, these factors enabled the community to create its unique scene, connected to a variety of local and international musical ‘worlds’.
